channel.title: CNN.com - Top Stories
channel.description: CNN.com delivers up-to-the-minute news and information on the latest top stories, weather, entertainment, politics and more.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 Cable News Network LP, LLLP.

image.title: CNN.com - Top Stories
image.description: CNN.com delivers up-to-the-minute news and information on the latest top stories, weather, entertainment, politics and more.

item.title: $53m in jewels taken in Cannes heist
item.description: An armed robber held up a jewelry exhibition in the French resort of Cannes, stealing jewels worth $53 million, police say.

item.title: Oliveira smashes blade runner record
item.description: Last year he shocked South Africa's Oscar Pistorius to win over 200m at the Paralympics and Sunday Brazil's Alan Oliveira returned to London's Olympic Stadium to prove he is the fastest amputee sprinter in the world.

item.title: Man sets fire to nursing home, 11 die
item.description: A squabble over $32 led a nursing home resident to set the building on fire, killing 11 people, Chinese state-run media reported.

item.title: Germany's women win Euro 2013
item.description: German goalkeeper Nadine Angerer achieved the rare feat of saving two penalties in a major football final to help her side beat Norway 1-0 Sunday to win Euro 2013.

item.title: 1,200 inmates break out of Libya prison
item.description: Libyan authorities are trying to round up a sea of inmates who escaped from a Benghazi prison.

item.title: Will China's economy crash?
item.description: Michael Pettis says China's GDP growth rate will likely decline in the coming years, but that's probably a good thing.

item.title: Sex researcher 'changed everything'
item.description: Virginia Johnson, with William Masters,revolutionized the world's understanding of human sexuality, and showed women that they--not men--could rule their bodies

item.title: How 'superwind' blows away stars
item.description: Meg Urry says new data have mapped a "superwind" flowing out of a nearby galaxy.

item.title: A rare look inside North Korea
item.description: CNN gets a rare look inside N. Korea as they mark the 60th anniversary of the end of the Korean War. Ivan Watson reports.

item.title: Why high-speed rail is safe, smart
item.description: This week's devastating crash of a high-speed train in Spain, which left nearly 80 dead, has drawn renewed attention to rail safety at a time when the Obama administration has prioritized the construction of fast new rail links.

item.title: 38 die after bus plunges from bridge in southern Italy
item.description: A bus carrying Catholic pilgrims in southern Italy strikes 11 cars before falling off a bridge, leaving at least 38 people dead.

item.title: Photos of deadly bus crash
item.description: Deadly bus crash in Italy

item.title: What caused crash?
item.description: At least 38 people were killed when a bus plunged off a highway bridge in Italy. Journalist Barbie Nadeau has more.

item.title: Fears of fresh Egypt crackdown
item.description: Egypt's interim president made an executive decision to transfer powers to the prime minister in the case of a state of emergency, state-run media reported.

item.title: Egypt defense chief rallies support
item.description: CNN's Ben Wedeman reports on Egypt's man of the moment: Defense Minister Abdel Fattah al-Sisi.

item.title: Syrian regime: Rebel haven falls
item.description: The Syrian regime says it has taken back a key area of Homs, inflicting a strategic blow to rebels fighting to end Bashar al-Assad's rule.

item.title: 43 killed in bombings across Iraq
item.description: A string of car and roadside bombs exploded across Iraq on Monday morning, killing at least 43 people and wounding nearly 200 others, police said.

item.title: Cambodian opposition rejects poll
item.description: The opposition in Cambodia says the election was marred by irregularities. Prime Minister Hun Sen won again after 28 years in office.

item.title: Mideast peace talks set to resume
item.description: With another round of Mideast peace talks set to begin, some observers see recent displays of goodwill as a positive sign -- some hint that these talks might finally prove to be fruitful, while others aren't as hopeful.

item.title: Bahrain passes stiffer 'terrorism' laws
item.description: Lawmakers in Bahrain have passed tough new laws for "terrorism acts" ahead of massive protests by the opposition on August 14, the state news agency BNA reported.

item.title: Bananas hurled at Italian minister
item.description: Bananas are thrown at Italy's first black minister Cecile Kyenge during a rally. The doctor's ascent to a top government position has stoked nativism.

item.title: Rioting after U.S. surf competition
item.description: First, police say, came a fight in a crowd at the end of a multiday surfing and skateboarding competition in Southern California's Huntington Beach on Sunday evening.

item.title: Tropical Storm Flossie nears Hawaii
item.description: Weakened but still bearing the promise of torrential rain, Tropical Storm Flossie spun slowly toward Hawaii on Monday.

item.title: 5 dead in Pennsylvania helicopter crash
item.description: Five people, including a child, died when their helicopter crashed in Wyoming County, Pennsylvania, that county's coroner said.

item.title: Venezuela president meets Fidel Castro
item.description: Cuban-state media on Sunday published photos of Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro meeting with former Cuban leader Fidel Castro in Havana.

item.title: Snedeker profits from Mahan's baby
item.description: It was a weekend that Brandt Snedeker and Hunter Mahan will never forget.

item.title: Sharapova injured ahead of U.S. Open
item.description: Maria Sharapova has been forced to pull out of the WTA Rogers Cup tournament in Toronto next month, still plagued by a nagging left hip injury.

item.title: 79 homicide charges for train driver
item.description: The 79 passengers who perished in last week's train crash in Spain will be memorialized together Monday night at a cathedral not far from where they were killed.

item.title: Lethal 'professional recklessness'
item.description: CNN's Karl Penhaul reports on the fate of the train driver in the high-speed derailment in Spain that killed at least 79.

item.title: Train driver accused of homicide
item.description: CNN's Karl Penhaul reports on the charges facing the driver of a high-speed train that crashed in Spain, killing dozens.

item.title: Video shows moment of impact
item.description: A deadly train crash in Spain was captured on closed circuit cameras. CNN's Karl Penhaul breaks down the dramatic video.

item.title: Vladimir Putin goes fishing
item.description: Russian President Vladimir Putin's latest adventure has him reportedly catching a 21 kilo pike while fishing in Siberia.

item.title: Pope: Being gay not a crime
item.description: On his flight back to Rome, Pope Francis tells reporters it is not a crime to be gay.

item.title: Rare JFK footage released
item.description: 50-year-old footage has been released of the Kennedys on vacation just four months before his assassination.

item.title: Balloon crashes into lake
item.description: Two people suffered minor injuries when a tourist hot-air balloon crashed into a lake in the Netherlands.

item.title: Horses served at the drive-thru?
item.description: Watch what happens when horses go through a McDonalds' drive-thru. CNN's Jeanne Moos reports on the ruckus.

item.title: Girl amuses dolphin
item.description: A girl's impromptu gymnastics performance appears to amuse her audience.

item.title: Soccer stars on Asia tour treadmill
item.description: He runs alongside the Arsenal coach in Vietnam's capital Hanoi mile after mile. He bumps into trees and lamp posts but keeps on running.

item.title: Celebrating Yadnya Kasada Festival
item.description: Throw it, catch it: Yadnya Kasada Festival

item.title: Australia's asylum plan: Dead in water?
item.description: Why Australia's plans to move asylum seekers to Papua New Guinea is doomed to fail.

item.title: Hollywood gets African makeover
item.description: What would The Matrix and other classic films look like if they'd been made in Africa?

item.title: Castro's son: I won't visit dad in prison
item.description: In his first television interview, Ariel Castro's son said Monday that his dad belongs in prison for the rest of his life and he doesn't plan on ever visiting him.

item.title: Mali rape victims tell of rebel horrors
item.description: Rebels in Mali are believed to have sexually assaulted thousands of women, Atika Shubert reports.

item.title: The future of global mapping
item.description: Mapping is said to be worth more than $150 billion a year, but many countries have yet to take the plunge.

item.title: Putin and the pike, and other adventures
Communism and dynasty in N. Korea
item.description: CNN's Ivan Watson finds Pyongyang is sticking to its style of communist and dynastic rule.

item.title: Ramadan acts as 'Super Bowl' for ads
item.description: For those that live and work in the Middle East, Ramadan is a period of considerable downtime. In many countries, special laws require the working day is reduced to accommodate those fasting (observers are meant to abstain from food, water, cigarettes -- even gossip -- during the daylight hours of the month-long holiday).

item.title: Oliveira: The new Blade Runner
item.description: Last year he shocked South Africa's Oscar Pistorius to win over 200m at the Paralympics and Sunday Brazil's Alan Oliveira returned to London's Olympic Stadium to prove he is the fastest amputee sprinter in the world.

item.title: The good and bad of sharing family names
item.description: His name has been passed down for eight generations. It's steeped in tradition and family pride. Oh -- but he's not the royal baby. He's William John Kane VIII, a database specialist from Portland, Oregon.

item.title: How Africa fuels your world
item.description: From PCs to cars, the products we take for granted are made with African minerals.

item.title: Africa's resources can halt poverty
item.description: A decade after Angola emerged from devastating civil war, the sea front road that winds around the bay of its capital, Luanda, is now dotted with multi-million dollar condominiums, exclusive clubs, and boutique stores catering for the country's elite.

item.title: Mining for minerals
item.description: Mining companies in Durban are eager to dig for minerals in the nearby dunes, but face opposition from environmentalists

item.title: Armed robber takes $53 million in jewels
item.description: A masked man threatens to shoot attendees at a Cannes exhibition.

item.title: Robber threatened to open fire
item.description: An armed robber stole $53 million in jewelry from an exhibition in Cannes, France.

item.title: NY's political sex scandal
item.description: It sounds like a plot line straight out of the TV show "Scandal:" In the midst of an attempted comeback, a disgraced politician finds himself tarred by a fresh round of lurid revelations.

item.title: Friend: Sexter 'idealized' Weiner
item.description: The woman at the center of the Anthony Weiner scandal is a 23-year-old Indiana native who is passionate about politics and was a strong supporter of the New York politician even after he resigned from Congress amid similar circumstances two years ago, a friend said.

item.title: Video gamers honor girl
item.description: Gamers are known as an abrasive lot -- but they have shown their sensitive side with a moving tribute to a young cancer victim.

item.title: Manning: Whistle-blower or traitor?
item.description: Was Pfc. Bradley Manning a brave patriot, or a reckless traitor whose leaks may have helped terrorists?

item.title: From slum to arty village
item.description: Modern art pops up in unexpected corners in Busan's Gamcheon Village.

item.title: How to watch China's pandas 24/7
item.description: Internet users love animal videos. So why not watch pandas -- anywhere, anytime?

item.title: China restores its 'national' car
item.description: China is reviving its former "national" car, the "Red Flag," as CNN's David McKenzie reports.

item.title: Soccer stars on Asia tour treadmill
item.description: He runs alongside the Arsenal coach in Vietnam's capital Hanoi mile after mile. He bumps into trees and lamp posts but keeps on running.

item.title: Could robots solve Detroit's crisis?
item.description: Detroit is in crisis, just as it was on the big screen in RoboCop. The film's writer says reality has almost caught up with his grim futuristic vision.

item.title: Oz's asylum plan: Dead in water?
item.description: Why Australia's plans to move asylum seekers to Papua New Guinea is doomed to fail.

item.title: African minerals fuel the world
item.description: From laptops to cars, the products we take for granted are made with African minerals.

item.title: Women: Cycling's 2nd-class citizens?
item.description: Could there soon be a Tour de France for women cyclists? The wheels of change are in motion.

item.title: Celebrating Yadnya Kasada
item.description: Throw it, catch it: Yadnya Kasada Festival

item.title: Hollywood gets African makeover
item.description: What would The Matrix and other classic films look like if they'd been made in Africa?

item.title: Would you visit a tyrants' lair?
item.description: With Adolf Hitler's WWII Bavarian mountain retreat set to undergo a multi-million dollar makeover, travel to the onetime lairs and luxury retreats of tyrants is in the spotlight.

item.title: N. Korea's propaganda parade
item.description: There was no verbal anti-U.S. rhetoric on North Korea's "Victory Day" but the message was clear.

item.title: 12 of world's dog-friendliest hotels
item.description: Last month, a British company launched the world's first dog-holiday package.

item.title: High society at play
item.description: Empires have been lost, the atom split, but some unique English sporting events remain the same.

item.title: Keeping Wimbledon green
item.description: The All England Club works to keep the grass looking great hosting Wimbledon and the Olympics.

item.title: Glamor at Royal Ascot
item.description: Winning Post's Francesca Cumani talks to fashion designer, Fitriani Hay about the glamor on display at Royal Ascot.

item.title: Could robots solve Detroit's crisis?
item.description: Detroit is in crisis, just as it was on the big screen in 1987's "RoboCop". The film's writer says reality has almost caught up with his grim futuristic vision.

item.title: Detroit: The city that 'used to be'
item.description: Heidi Ewing, filming her documentary about Detroit, found desperate people living on the margins, but also folks who are trying to make the city as vibrant as people say it used to be.

item.title: Can Detroit reinvent itself?
item.description: Maggie Lake speaks with Bruce Katz from the Brookings Institute about reasons to be optimistic about a Detroit revival.

item.title: Tears flow with mud
item.description: Rain forces a change in the pope's plans, devastating traders who borrowed heavily to cater for crowds.

item.title: Francis wades into favelas
item.description: The man widely revered as the "Slum Pope" wades into the favelas of Rio de Janeiro. CNN's Shasta Darlington reports.

item.title: How should Twitter tackle trolls?
item.description: Tweeted threats aimed at a feminist who campaigned to have women displayed on UK banknotes spark outrage and calls for Twitter to do more to fight trolls.

item.title: Pope: 'Who am I to judge' gay clergy
item.description: Pope Francis tells reporters that it is not a crime to be gay.

item.title: Spanish train charges
item.description: The 79 passengers who perished in last week's train crash in Spain will be memorialized together Monday night at a cathedral not far from where they were killed.

item.title: Iraq bombs
item.description: A string of car and roadside bombs exploded across Iraq on Monday morning, killing at least 43 people and wounding nearly 200 others, police said.

item.title: Italy crash
item.description: A bus returning pilgrims from a weekend visit to a Catholic shrine went off a bridge in southern Italy on Sunday, leaving at least 24 dead, including some children, the Italian news agency ANSA reported.

item.title: Egypt unrest
item.description: Egypt's interim president has allowed for the prime minister to assume presidential powers in the case of a state of emergency -- stoking fears of a fierce crackdown on supporters of the recently ousted president.

item.title: Israel prisoner release
item.description: Israel will release 104 Palestinian prisoners as a first step toward renewed peace talks. Fionnuala Sweeney reports.

item.title: Italy racism
item.description: Racist taunts against Italy's first black minister, Cecile Kyenge, took another ugly turn over the weekend when someone hurled bananas at her during a rally.

item.title: Cambodia poll
item.description: The opposition party in Cambodia has rejected the results of the country's national election, which handed another win to long-serving Prime Minister Hun Sen.

item.title: $53M heist
item.description: $53 Million Dollars worth of diamond jewelry stolen from a famous French hotel. CNN's Erin McLaughlin reports.

item.title: Urban oasis for Haiti's poorest
item.description: Living amid the garbage-strewn sewage canals, residents of Haiti's Cite Soleil endure a grim battle for survival every single day.

item.title: Why urban gardens can cut obesity
item.description: What's better than fresh, locally grown fruits and vegetables? How about fresh, locally-grown, free fruits and vegetables, all within an easy walk of your home or office?

item.title: Family farming to cut poverty
item.description: In just 12 years leading up to 2010, Vietnam cut the country's malnutrition rate in half by investing in small scale farming.

item.title: The true cost of supersized portions
item.description: We're all familiar with the phrase "waste not, want not," but how well are we applying these words today?

item.title: Study: Air pollution kills two million
item.description: More than two million people are dying every year from the effects of outdoor air pollution, according to a new study.

item.title: The world's vanishing glaciers
item.description: The melting glacial ice in places like the Alps, Greenland and the Himalayas is a dramatic visual document of how our planet's climate is changing.

item.title: Oceans: Eco-victim or savior?
item.description: My grandfather Jacques Cousteau and my father Philippe dedicated their lives to revealing the ocean's wonders and helping us understand our connection to this vast expanse of water. Their work inspired generations and filled people with awe.

item.title: Island nations at risk
item.description: Kieren Keke remembers growing up on the Pacific island of Nauru, the world's smallest independent republic.

item.title: How trees must adapt to drought
item.description: Scientists have known for some time that climate change and the impacts of longer droughts and higher temperatures could pose a problem for forests. But many thought it would only affect a minority of trees, perhaps just those in extremely arid regions.

item.title: How climate impacts food supply
item.description: Sometimes Jaria Faraj Ali is so hungry that she ties a scarf tight around her waist to make her feel more comfortable.

item.title: Cousteau meets wetland wildlife
item.description: Philippe Cousteau explores the largest environmental restoration project ever attempted in the Florida Everglades.

item.title: Ice melt speeding up, study finds
item.description: Two decades of satellite readings back up what dramatic pictures have suggested in recent years: The mile-thick ice sheets that cover Greenland and most of Antarctica are melting at a faster rate in a warming world.

item.title: Permit problems for tallest 'building'
item.description: The plan to raise what would be the world's tallest building in a dizzyingly fast time is in danger of not getting off the ground at all.

item.title: GSK's China bribery scandal
item.description: An investigation by Chinese authorities into the activities of GlaxoSmithKline has allegedly turned up a bribery network that involves government officials, doctors, hospitals and at least 700 travel agencies.

item.title: China's city of sinkholes
item.description: Four months after he built a new, two-story brick house in his village in northern China's Shandong Province, Xiao Guoqiang was alarmed to find a huge crack on the living room wall.

item.title: Bo Xilai indicted
item.description: For more than a year, Bo Xilai has been the elephant in the room in Chinese politics -- the central figure in one of the messiest political scandals to hit the ruling Communist Party in years.

item.title: No more bling for Beijing?
item.description: Some state-run enterprises in China have opulent headquarters more suited to the court of Louis XIV of France, while other local government-owned buildings even replicate the home of the President of the United States.

item.title: Quake hits northwest China
item.description: Rescue teams are scrambling to reach the site of Monday morning's strong and shallow earthquake in northwestern China that has killed at least 89 people, according to state media.

item.title: 'Shameful' treatment of HK refugees
item.description: On the surface, Hong Kong transmits an image of prosperity, comfort and convenience.

item.title: Is 'Chinese dream' a fantasy?
item.description: What is the president's "Chinese Dream"? And is it what the people want? Kristie Lu Stout asks around.

item.title: Transcript: The Chinese Dream
item.description: This episode's guests include Wu Jianmin, Former Chinese Ambassador to the United Nations; Evan Osnos, Former Beijing Correspondent, The New Yorker; and Jing Ulrich, Chairman, Global Markets, China, JP Morgan.

item.title: Asiana crash probe closes at airport
item.description: The National Transportation Safety Board has wrapped up its on-scene work as part of its investigation of the Asiana Flight 214 crash at San Francisco airport, the agency said Monday.

item.title: Apple to probe electrocution
item.description: U.S. electronics giant Apple is investigating reports in China that a woman died after being electrocuted while trying to make a call with her iPhone 5 while it was charging.
